New pay scale set for workers
Hopkins' central
administration has almost
completed instituting a uniform
pay scale for non-faculty
University employees, a
long-term plan aimed at ensuring
compliance with the Fair Labor
Standards act and the Equal Pay
amendment.
The adjustment of employee
salaries is "about 95 per cent
completed" on the Homewood
campus, while Hopkins' Health
Services division may not
complete the re-classification for
several months, according to
William Pipkin, director of
Personnel Services.
The pay scale encompasses all
University administrative
positions with the exception of
corporate offices, such as division
Presidents and Vice Presidents.
Pipkin said that a task force
comprised of Homewood and
central administration officers
reassessed the "skill, effort, and
responsibility" required for each
position, as stipulated in the Fair
Labor Standards act. The group
then established a salary range
for each job.
At present, Pipkin stated, all

Homewood employees are being
reimbursed above the minimum
of their specified pay range. "The
first effect of the reassessment,"
he said, "was that any employee
who had been salaried below the
minimum established was raised
to at least the minimum."
All salaries will not be adjusted
within- the assessed range for
some time, though. "Starting a
plan like this is like boarding a
train in motion," he explained.
"We can't arbitrarily change or
reduce salaries to conform with
the scale."
"The remaining changes will
be phased in over some period of
time," he added.
Pipkin said he believes the
uniform pay scale, in addition to
facilitating compliance with
federal legislation, will improve
emplyee morale somewhat. "All
management theoriests say that
equitable pay is a necessity for
employee satisfaction," he
stated. "With a uniform pay
system, employees can be
completely certain that they are
being reimbursed fairly."
During the course of the job
reassessment, all employees filled

out a job description
questionnaire which was
reviewed and supplemented by
department supervisors.
The supervisors also
participated in what Pipkin terms
"the validation step," in which
the new job code and the method
of assessment were
dem onstrated.
Pipkin said that in some cases
the code was modified on the
recommendation of supervisors,
who had first-hand knowledge of
the responsibilities of specific
positions.

Traffic and Parking policy for the
Homewood Campus will become

be discontinued.
(3) Vehicles in parking lots

expense if there are two or more
unpaid fines outstanding against

parked on campus roadways,
lawns, delivery entrances or
service areas will continue to be
subject to towing, in accordance
with the current policy.

Because of a local
interpretation of the income tax
child care deduction laws,
students and post-doctoral
fellows in the Baltimore area may
not deduct child-care expenses
on their federal tax returns.
Students whose income tax
returns are being audited can
expect to be assessed for back
taxes and the accompanying fines
for any child care deductions
taken under the Revenue Act of
1971.
Internal Revenue Service
agents in other states have
interpreted the law differently so
that students are eligible for child
care deductions.
Concerning itself with "certain
expenses for household and
dependent care services necessary
to be gainfully employed," the
Revenue Act of 1971 allows
deductions "for 'employment
related expenses incurred in any
month only to the extent that
such expenses do not exceed
$400." These "employment
related expenses" are defined as
"expenses for household services,
and expenses for the care of
qualifying individual."
However, according to an
auditor in the Baltimore office of
the IRS, students, specifically
graduate and post-doctoral
students, are not .considered
"gainfully employed," and
therefore ineligible for the

deduction, as some audited
students have already learned.
Hopkins post-doctorate fellow
Dr. Alan Friedman is one
example. Informed that the IRS
was auditing his tax returns of
the past several years, he
discovered that he was not
considered eligible for the child
care deduction.
Friedman has since
contacted a lawyer who says that
it looks as if his case can be won

post-doctoral fellow.
While $300 per month of his
stipend under existing laws is tax

taxable. The IRS claims that the
money does not constitute
gainful employment.

my education, but not the
money."

Hopkins' central
administration has almost
completed instituting a uniform
pay scale for non-faculty
University employees, a
long-term plan aimed at ensuring
compliance with the Fair Labor
Standards act and the Equal Pay
amendment.
The adjustment of employee
salaries is "about 95 per cent
completed" on the Homewood
campus, while Hopkins' Health
Services division may not
complete the re-classification for
several months, according to
William Pipkin, director of
Personnel Services.

central administration officers

position, as stipulated in the Fair
Labor Standards act. The group

first effect of the reassessment,"

who had been salaried below the
minimum established was raised
to at least the minimum."
All salaries will not be adjusted
within- the assessed range for
some time, though. "Starting a
plan like this is like boarding a
train in motion," he explained.
"We can't arbitrarily change or
reduce salaries to conform with
the scale."
"The remaining changes will
be phased in over some period of
time," he added.
Pipkin said he believes the
uniform pay scale, in addition to
facilitating compliance with
federal legislation, will improve
emplyee morale somewhat. "All
management theoriests say that
equitable pay is a necessity for
employee satisfaction," he
stated. "With a uniform pay
system, employees can be
completely certain that they are
being reimbursed fairly."
During the course of the job
reassessment, all employees filled

out a job description
questionnaire which was
reviewed and supplemented by
department supervisors.
The supervisors also
participated in what Pipkin terms
"the validation step," in which
the new job code and the method

the code was modified on the
recommendation of supervisors,
who had first-hand knowledge of
the responsibilities of specific
positions.

Because of a local
interpretation of the income tax
child care deduction laws,
students and post-doctoral
fellows in the Baltimore area may
not deduct child-care expenses
on their federal tax returns.
Students whose income tax
returns are being audited can
expect to be assessed for back
taxes and the accompanying fines
for any child care deductions
taken under the Revenue Act of
1971.
Internal Revenue Service
agents in other states have
interpreted the law differently so
that students are eligible for child
care deductions.
Concerning itself with "certain
expenses for household and
dependent care services necessary
to be gainfully employed," the
Revenue Act of 1971 allows
deductions "for 'employment
related expenses incurred in any
month only to the extent that
such expenses do not exceed
$400." These "employment
related expenses" are defined as
"expenses for household services,
and expenses for the care of
qualifying individual."
However, according to an
auditor in the Baltimore office of
the IRS, students, specifically
graduate and post-doctoral
students, are not .considered
"gainfully employed," and
therefore ineligible for the

deduction, as some audited
students have already learned.
Hopkins post-doctorate fellow
Dr. Alan Friedman is one
example. Informed that the IRS
was auditing his tax returns of
the past several years, he
discovered that he was not
considered eligible for the child
care deduction.
Friedman has since
contacted a lawyer who says that
it looks as if his case can be won
in court, but only because he is a
post-doctoral fellow.
While $300 per month of his
stipend under existing laws is tax
free, the rest of the money is
taxable. The IRS claims that the
money does not constitute
gainful employment.
However, Friedman holds that
the money is indeed gainful
employment, since he must leave
his home and work at the
University project in order to
earn his money.
"If I had stayed home with my
kids," he says, "I'd have gotten
my education, but not the
money."
